column1: File:Ted Nasmith - The Dawn of the Firstborn Elves.jpg - The Dawn of the Firstborn Elves
Owing to their longevity
column2: the Elves had a very different Life cycle than Men. Most of the following information strictly refers only to the Eldar—but much could probably be applied to the Avari as well.

column1: ==Early life==
File:Jenny Dolfen - Feanoreans - Family picture.jpg - Family picture
Elves are born about one year after their begetting. The day of their begetting is remembered
column2: not the actual birthday itself
column3: because bringing forth children is an act of will
column4: and it required a "greater share and strength of their being
column5: in mind and in body" than takes place "in the making of mortal children." By their first year
column9: and their quicker onset of mental maturity makes young Elves seem older than they actually are. Physical puberty is generally complete by their fiftieth year (by age fifty they reach their adult height)
column10: but they are not considered full-grown until a hundred years have passed.

column1: Elves bodies developed slower than those of Men
column2: but their minds developed more swiftly. In their twenties
column3: they might still appear physically seven years old
column4: though the Elf-child would have mature language and skill
column5: whereas Men at the same age are already physically mature.

column1: ==Sexuality
column2: marriage

column1: File:Līga Kļaviņa - Love at First Sight.jpg - Love at First Sight
Elves marry for love
column2: or at least with free will from both parties
column3: typically early in life. Monogamy is practised and adultery is unthinkable. By their very nature
column4: they are "seldom swayed by the desires of the body" or influenced by lust. They marry only once for it was ruled by Manwë that
column5: "since the Elves are by nature permanent in life within Arda
column6: so also is their unmarred marriage." Finwë
column7: first High King of the Noldor
column8: was an exception. After his Míriel died
column9: from passing the majority of her life into Fëanor
column11: Finwë was permitted to marry again. This was pronounced by Mandos as the Doom of Finwë and Míriel.

column1: Spouses may choose each other
column2: in their youth
column3: long before they are married and be betrothed. The betrothal is subject to parental approval from both houses unless the parties are of age and intend to marry soon. At which point
column4: the betrothal is announced at a meeting of the two houses
column5: during which the couple exchange silver rings. The betrothal lasts at least a year. A betrothal is revocable by a public return of the rings
column7: but revocation was rarely needed because "the Eldar do not err lightly" in the choice of their partner. After their formal betrothal
column8: the couple appoints a time for the wedding when at least a year has passed.

column1: Marriage is celebrated at a feast of the two houses. The spouses return their betrothal rings
column2: which they keep
column3: and receive "slender rings of gold" which are worn upon "the index of the right hand." In Noldor tradition
column4: the bride’s mother gives the groom a jewel to be worn and the bridegrooms father gives a similar gift to the bride. These ceremonies and traditions were only a way for the parents to show their love and to mark a respectful recognition of the two houses which would be joined. While it was considered "ungracious and contemptuous of kin"
column7: it was completely lawful for a couple to be married without them. The indissoluble union was completed solely by the act of bodily union" which achieved marriage. Technically
column9: only blessings exchanged between the bride and groom
column10: including speaking of the name of Eru
column11: and consummation are required for marriage.

column1: File:Tuuliky - Lumen Melma.jpg - Lumen Melma

The Elves view the sexual act as extremely special for "the union of love is indeed to them great delight and joy." Extra-marital sex would be against their nature because they can "read at once in the eyes and voice of another whether they be wed or unwed"; they would release their own spirit to Mandos before succumbing to rape
column2: and premarital sex would create marriage which makes the term itself a misnomer. "There is no record of any among the Elves that actually took anothers spouse by force" though Maeglin made the wrongful attempt to steal Idril.

column1: Spouses can sometimes live separately for extended periods of time. Though united in body and spirit
column2: they remain individuals with different gifts of mind and body to pursue. However
column3: a sundering during pregnancy or during the early years of parenthood
column5: would be so grievous to the couple
column7: that they prefer to have children in peaceful times.

column1: Elves typically have four children or fewer. Fëanor and Nerdanel
column2: who had seven sons
column3: were a notable exception. Whenever the Eldar married
column4: whether in youth or in later life
column5: their children were produced within a relatively short time after their wedding. However
column7: a century or two may pass before the begetting of the first child and even longer between child and child. After their time of children
column8: the desire to procreate soon ceases. They turn their powers of body and mind to other tasks and arts. Nonetheless
column9: they cherish the days of bearing and raising children as the happiest times of their lives.

column1: There are examples that appear to contradict this ideal. An example of extreme marital strife among the Eldar is the case of Eöl and Aredhel
column2: where Eöl tried to restrain his wife from living the life of her choice. As a result
column3: Aredhel left Eöl without his knowing
column6: with her back to Gondolin. The end result was that Eöl sought revenge upon his own family
column7: and while seeking to slay his rebellious son
column8: slew his wife accidentally. Another example of great discontent developed between Fëanor and Nerdanel after the theft of the Silmarils. Nerdanel did not wish to be parted from all her children nor did she wish to follow her husband against the Valars wishes. Fëanors harsh response was that
column9: if she would not follow him
column10: she was an untrue wife for deserting both her husband and her children.

column1: Celegorms pursuit of Lúthien and Maeglins attraction to Idril are cases of elves who sought disinterested partners. The desire for these unwilling wives was mixed with a desire for power. While unrequited love was known to happen
column2: few of the Eldar responded so negatively to it. Indis loved Finwë with secret admiration but remained contently unwed because he was married. Turgon
column4: denied Maeglins suit for Idrils hand because he believed that Maeglin sought power more than the love of his daughter. In Celegorms case
column5: he was motivated to claim Lúthien as his bride to force her father
column7: to ally with the Fëanorians during the Siege of Angband. However
column9: against the attempted bride-stealing by Celegorm and the later attack by Curufin.

column1: ==Daily life==
Elves preoccupy themselves with various arts
column2: such as: smithwork
column7: and healing. Males and females have equal skill in all things
column8: not concerned with the bringing forth of children; however
column9: the females often specialize in the arts of healing while the men go to war. This is because the Elves believe that taking life interferes with the ability to preserve life. Women who hunted would not specialize in healing
column10: and men who healed would refrain from hunting and only fight when absolutely necessary
column11: for "the virtue . . . in this matter of healing was due . . . to their abstaining from hunting or war." Elves do not have rigid gender roles though natural inclinations were recognized
column12: which varied based on the time and place and among the different peoples of Elves.

column1: ==Later life==
File:Jef Murray - Cirdan.jpg - Cirdan
Eventually
column2: if they did not die in battle or from some other cause
column5: of Middle-earth grew weary and desired to go to Valinor
column6: where the Valar sheltered their kind. This was known as the sea-longing. Those who wished to leave for the Undying Lands went by ships provided at the Grey Havens
column7: where Círdan the Shipwright dwelt with his folk. Those
column9: who did not perish through bodily death or depart from Middle-earth across the sea would eventually fade. Fading occurred when their fëar consumed their bodies and the body became merely a memory of the fëa. In this state
column10: "they were open to the direct instruction and command of the Valar" and as soon as they were disembodied in this way they would be summoned to the Halls of Waiting in Aman.

column1: =="Cycles of life" and ageing==
Elves had no beards
column2: at least until their "third cycle of life"
column3: like Círdan. Mahtan was an exception
column4: and had a beard in his early "second cycle". The Elvish beardlessness could also be observed in Mannish lines with an Elvish strain (as in the princely house of Dol Amroth)

column1: While the three cycles are not specifically defined
column2: the first cycle is likely childhood and adolescence
column4: the second is adulthood which could continue for Ages
column5: and the third is for extremely old Elves; Círdan was the most ancient known Elf in Middle-earth. However
column6: Elves who were not ancient could enter the third stage sooner due to tragic life events. When Lúthien wilfully released her spirit to follow Beren
column9: as it were the hoar age of mortal Men

column1: Apparently
column2: beards
column4: were the only sign of further natural physical ageing beyond maturity.

column1: Elves did not physically age after they reached maturity
column2: but they did age in a different sense than Men. They became ever more weary of the world and burdened by its sorrows. Círdan seemed to be aged himself since he is described as looking old
column3: save for the stars in his eyes; this may be due to all the sorrows he had seen and lived through since the First Age. He had been one of the Teleri on the Great Journey who tarried on the shores of Middle-earth for Thingols sake
column5: though he had greatly wished to go to Aman. Another aged elf was Gwindor
column6: the people of Nargothrond had trouble recognizing him after he escaped from being a prisoner of Morgoth in the pits of Angband for fourteen years.

column1: Another bearded elf was possibly Tinfang Gelion.
==Death and reincarnation==
File:Ted Nasmith - The Light of Valinor on the Western Sea.jpg - The Light of Valinor on the Western Sea
Elves are naturally immortal; like the Ainur
column2: they are bound to Arda until its End. Elves are immune to all diseases
column3: and they can recover from wounds which would normally kill a mortal Man.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: Elves can be physically slain or die of grief and weariness. Death was unnatural for Elves; Ilúvatar intended for an Elfs spirit  (Fëa and hröa) and body (Fëa and hröa) to remain united throughout the entire life of Arda
column3: but this design was disrupted by evils of Melkor. Should an Elf die
column4: its spirit would be summoned to the Halls of Mandos in Aman. Elves could refuse the summons
column5: but this would suggest that they were tainted. Elves who went to the Halls were
column7: typically given the opportunity to be reincarnated into a body identical to the one that died. If the Elf accepted the opportunity
column8: the Valar would then create the new body for the Elfs spirit; Elven spirits had no power to build such bodies for themselves. But the Valar could
column9: if an Elf committed evil acts and refused to repent or continued to feel ill-will towards others
column10: delay the time of the reincarnation
column11: impose conditions of an Elfs return
column12: or refuse to re-embody an Elf altogether (as was done with Fëanor). An Elven spirit could also choose to remain disembodied; the Valar had no authority to force Elves to reincarnate.

column1: Before the Downfall of Númenor
column2: Elves who died in Middle-earth and were re-embodied in Aman could return to Middle-earth if they wished
column4: as the journey was dangerous and they risked dying again. However
column5: while the Noldor were Exiled in the First Age
column6: the Valar physically barred travel between Aman and Middle-earth; the only Elf who died and was allowed to return to Middle-earth during this period was Lúthien
column7: and through the grace of Ilúvatar
column8: she returned as a mortal. Glorfindel
column9: who died in the Fall of Gondolin
column10: was reincarnated and returned to Middle-earth
column11: most likely in the Second Age by way of Númenor. After the Downfall of Númenor and the removal of Aman and Tol Eressëa from the Circles of the World near the end of the Second Age
column12: Ilúvatar decreed that Elves were no longer permitted to travel to Middle-earth.
